results.title: 1957 Pig Carcase Competition
results.brief_description: Details and promotes the 1957 Pig Carcase competition as well as pork production in Victoria as a whole. Similar to the 1955 Pig Carcase competition in format and style. Includes various shots of carcases being cut for display, general crowd shots, an awards ceremony and a speech by an official. Features fantastic footage of three carcases hanging up in front of a black backdrop being inspected and caressed by a man. Nice theatrical quality to it. Excellent shot of a boy inspecting pork shot from behind, highlighting very cute jeans. End of piece features an official from the Board of Meat, aided by illustrations, talking about how pork production in Victoria has improved over time. Behind him hang carcases and behind them there is a red wall. He wears a pink and red tie. This creates a quirky, very good-looking frame of man, meat and pig illustration. Soundtrack features music of the period and earnest narration about ‘pig raisers’.

results.title: Police horses: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters
results.brief_description:
Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters

results.title: Melbourne (no. 3)
results.brief_description: Film features quite general shots of Melbourne in the summer. This includes footage of the Great Ocean Road (including panoramas), a busy suburban pool and St. Kilda Beach. These sequences have a great, nostalgic ‘good time’ vibe to them, which is aided in part by the high-contrast film stock. There is also footage of one of Melbourne’s Gardens (possibly the Botanic), including blooming flowers and people looking at them. Nice shots of man burning leaves followed by the sun breaking through smoke haze and trees in garden. Two shots include views of St. Paul’s Cathederal and the Forum Theatre from the Yarra. Nice, Black and White ‘The End’.

results.title: Potash deficiency Hamilton district
results.brief_description: No sound. Long-duration shots of clovers, fields and farmers walking through fields. Ends with footage of a manually-operated farming device that either plants seeds or removes plants.

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: My journey to strength
results.brief_description: Hilda suffers from deafness and here she gives a frank account of the ups and downs in her life and the traumatic effect of losing her mum just before she turned 18. Through support and determination she has survived years of depression and finally found happiness and acceptance. With subtitles.
results.description: Hilda suffers from deafness and here she gives a frank account of the ups and downs in her life and the traumatic effect of losing her mum just before she turned 18. results.title: Weekends in the country
results.brief_description: Born in the country but forced to live in a hostel for the deaf in Melbourne from a very young age, William talks about his isolation, depression and separation from family. This is a tragic story reflecting the lack of facilities and support for the deaf in rural Victoria. With Auslan signing and subtitles.
